title: Discussing Scientific Processes and Innovations
description: Practice describing scientific processes, discussing innovations, and using passive and causative structures in speech.

sentences.text: The experiment was conducted under strictly controlled laboratory conditions.
sentences.translation: 실험은 엄격히 통제된 실험실 조건에서 수행되었다.
sentences.tips: Passive voice emphasizes the action rather than who did it.

sentences.text: New treatments are being developed that could revolutionize cancer care.
sentences.translation: 암 치료를 혁신할 수 있는 새로운 치료법이 개발되고 있다.
sentences.tips: Present continuous passive for ongoing processes.

sentences.text: The data needs to be analyzed before any conclusions can be drawn.
sentences.translation: 어떤 결론을 내리기 전에 데이터가 분석되어야 한다.

sentences.text: We had the samples tested at an independent laboratory.
sentences.translation: 우리는 독립 연구소에서 샘플을 테스트하게 했다.
sentences.tips: Causative 'have something done' for services by others.

sentences.text: It is believed that artificial intelligence will transform healthcare.
sentences.tips: Impersonal passive for reporting general beliefs.

sentences.text: The vaccine has been administered to millions of people worldwide.
sentences.translation: 백신은 전 세계 수백만 명에게 투여되었다.
sentences.tips: Present perfect passive for completed actions with present relevance.

sentences.text: The professor made the students repeat the experiment until the results could be replicated.
sentences.translation: 교수는 결과가 재현될 수 있을 때까지 학생들에게 실험을 반복하게 했다.
sentences.tips: Causative 'make someone do' followed by passive 'could be replicated'.

sentences.text: The research facility is having a new wing built to accommodate more scientists.
sentences.translation: 연구 시설은 더 많은 과학자를 수용하기 위해 새로운 동을 짓게 하고 있다.
sentences.tips: Present continuous causative 'is having something done'.

sentences.text: Clinical trials must be completed before the drug can be approved.
sentences.translation: 약이 승인되기 전에 임상 시험이 완료되어야 한다.
sentences.tips: Modal passive 'must be completed' and 'can be approved'.

sentences.text: The algorithm was designed to detect patterns that humans might miss.
sentences.translation: 그 알고리즘은 인간이 놓칠 수 있는 패턴을 감지하도록 설계되었다.
sentences.tips: Simple past passive for completed design.

sentences.text: We got the ethics committee to approve the methodology.
sentences.tips: Causative 'get someone to do' requires 'to' before the verb.

sentences.text: It has been reported that a breakthrough in fusion energy is imminent.
sentences.tips: Present perfect impersonal passive for recent reports.

lines.text: How is the new project progressing?
Very well. The initial phase has been completed, and data is now being collected from participants.
Have the samples been analyzed yet?
Not yet. We're having them tested at a specialized facility. The results should be ready next week.
I heard there were some concerns about the methodology.
Yes, but those have been addressed. We got the ethics committee to review everything, and modifications were made based on their feedback.
What about the timeline? Will deadlines be met?
We believe so. It is expected that the paper will be submitted by the end of the quarter.
If accepted, it could be published within six months. The findings are significant, so peer review should go smoothly.
That's exciting. What happens next with the funding?
We're having a new grant proposal drafted. If approved, more researchers will be hired and the project can be expanded.

items: Did you pronounce passive verb forms clearly?
Did you stress key scientific vocabulary correctly?
Did you use appropriate intonation for statements and questions?
Did you link words naturally in longer sentences?
Did you use passive structures smoothly without hesitation?
Did you incorporate causative structures naturally?
Did you complete complex sentences without excessive pauses?
Did you maintain flow when switching between active and passive?
Did you form passive structures correctly (be + past participle)?
Did you use causative 'have/get something done' correctly?
Did you use 'make/have/let/get someone do' with correct verb forms?
Did you use impersonal passives (It is believed...) appropriately?
Did you describe scientific processes clearly?
Did you use appropriate technical vocabulary?
Did you explain complex ideas in an organized manner?
Did you respond appropriately to questions in the dialogue?
